description.text:
This holds wire spools, keeping them neat and allowing easy access to sizes and colors. The holes in the end provide a place to store pencils, tweezers, odds and ends. In the WireSpoolHolder version, if you set skeinforge to a dense fill, the bottom will be heavier than the top, providing extra stability.
Also, you can attach sticky sided velcro to the bottom for added holding down to a desktop.

There are two versions, WireSpoolHolder has a fill in the bottom third to add some extra weight there.  WireSpoolHolderShell has no fill in the bottom.
Print the file twice and then connect the notches with a 5 mm diameter rod and put the wire spools on the rod.
I uploaded both the Sketchup format files and the stl output files.

title: 2020 I-Type 5 Extrusion Cable Clip with groove for small wires.

description.text:
I build the aweseom Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D printer http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:811271 and needed some good way to fix my wires instead of just using zip-ties. I found a super good collections of cable clips at https://www.youmagine.com/designs/a-bunch-of-2020-misumi-cable-clips but I just needed 1 special clip to hold in the 2 wires for my LEDs. To make sure it is clear:
This is a remix from a model from the "a bunch of 2020 Misumi Cable Clips" collection over at:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/a-bunch-of-2020-misumi-cable-clips

Fill up your plate and print a lot at a time.  
I printed some with 20 infill and 3 periemters and some with 100% infill. They all work, but might as well do it 100% as they are much stiffer and stay that way, much better. It doesn't take much more plastic to fill it out anyway.  
I used 0,2 layer heigh and a 0.4 nozzle.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iUK85VttmGU

A simple celtic weave pattern bent into a circle. It is a little too detailed for my printer as you can see from the pic, but this would look nice on a better printer. Anyway, I am going to reduce the density of the weave in a future version, so you can see the detail more when printed at home. Also a wrist cuff version would be fun to do as well. The diameter of this first try is toooo big! Almost 100mm or 4". So if you print this, print at about 70% scale. I'll upload smaller versions soon. V2 Uploaded. description.text: Filadelphia is a standalone filament holder that prints in one piece without any supports on a Makerbot Replicator 2 with PLA. Everything is modeled under angle so the wheels axes spin and stay in place without any assembly or additional parts or screws : Just print 4 of them, fold out the stands & click them together. As proof of concept here's a timelapse of printing 8 Filadelphias (8 hours) ... fed by earlier printed Filadelphias : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_c32D4GcHnY Here you can see how multiple Filadelphias can interconnect in order to put multiple rails next to each other : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oyPpUEeihMw

Filadelphia was created from scratch in Blender and printed in PLA with Makerbot Desktop Beta 3.7.0.108. I found that printing in standard (0.2mm) resolution gave the best results. It takes about 1 hour to print one object and I can print 8 at once. Here's how it comes off the raft and folds open : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gZvuMnsu6YY As you can see the wheels spin perfectly (and actually a lot better than I ever expected :) ).
Although it stands perfectly on it's own I provided a screw hole for those that want to fix it in a more permanent way. With the pads folded in you can mount two rails closely together and save space. The pieces may feel be a bit hard to click together but we want them secured and that didn't work perfectly with earlier (more lose) tests. I've added a 'connector' (removed the wheel & holder) to fit in between two rails and a double version as well.

I design this simple GoPro filter mount in order to use 30mm filter (Polarized, Neutral Density, ...) without having something too heavy.
You can use this filter mount with GoPro 3 and 4 (no tested with other version of GoPro).
For exemple if you want to remove the jello effect, you can use a ND8 filter.
The total weight of a polarized filter and this mount is only 4g

Printed with 100% infill
No need to glue the 2 parts
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:998600 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=998600

Using the following options: HeightHolder = 50
Slices = 260
Radius = 4.5
Holes = 6
Print & Use !
this is a simple design optimal for almost any spool.
you just need to print two of all the file to have a fully functional spool holder. if you want you cant even use bearings instead of the rings to make it work even better

This design not a simply spoolholder, also shows you its approximate weight. The parts that are not 3D printing is a steel rod 8mm in diameter which holds the spool and 4 screws 3mm in diameter, all other parts are to print on any 3D printer even spring.   
Each Design fits within a build volume of 25.2 x 19.9x 15.0h cm.  
Este diseño no solo sostiene el filamento sino que tambien te muestra su peso aproximado. Llas unicas piezas que no son de impresion 3D son una barra de acero de 8mm de diametro la cual sostiene el rollo y 4 tornillos de 3mm de diametro, todas las demas piezas son para imprimir en cualquier impresora 3D incluso el resorte.  
Cada diseño cabe en un espacio de construccion de 25.2 x 19.9 x 15.0 cm.

With only 9 pieces it is fairly intuitive to assemble but still have some recommendations:
1) printing on ABS "resorte 1.5" because I had no time to measure the spring constant in other materials such as PLA
2) the piece called "tope" is placed in the raised section of the piece "aguja"
3) Do not place more than 3 kg
4) screw holes in the pieces "cobertor resorte" and "cobertor aguja" are covered by a thin layer that is easy to remove which serves as a support for subsequent layers.
5) Last but not least it is that all parts printed them with an extruder with layers of 0.5mm to 0.3mm ecepccion of the piece "aguja" that printed it in layers of 0.2mm for rigidity. Con solo 9 piezas es bastante intuitiva de armar pero aun asi tengo algunas recomendaciones:
1) imprimir en ABS "resorte 1.5" ya que no tuve tiempo de medir la constande del resorte en otro material como el PLA
2) la pieza que tiene como nombre "tope" se coloca en la guia de la aguja
3) no colocar objetos que pesen mas de 3 Kg
4) los agujeros de los tornillos en las piezas "cobertor resorte" y "cobertor aguja" estan tapados por una fina capa que es facil de quitar la cual sirve de soporte para las capas subsiguientes.
5) la ultima pero no menos importante es que todas las piezas las imprimi con un extrusor de 0.5mm con capas de 0.3mm a ecepccion de la pieza "aguja" que la imprimi en capas de 0.2mm para mayor rigidez.

description.text: For the pop-up washer cover connect to actuator

Whole modification of the QAV250 :
  • VTX / LIPO buzzer support
  • Flightboard / receiver plate
  • Antenna hold
  • Back light
  • Camera support (Sony Effio from Hobbyking)
    • The camera support is a remake (back and support) of this design : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:548679 Cloverleaf protection done is from this design : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:813954 This design is for a Naze32 flight board, for a Pixhawk Lite flight board see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1044405 See instructions for more details

Everything was printed with 100% infill, except qav250_light printed at 15% infill If you want to :
  • Hold your antenna, use support-antenne-qav.stl
  • Have back light, use qav250_light.stl
  • Mount video transmitter and lipo alarm, use ts5823.stl and ts5823-rondelle.stl
  • Move the flight board, hold a buzzer and fix your D4R receiver, use qav250-plate.stl and support-transfo.stl
  • Add a camera, use sony_effio_back.stl, sony_effio_front.stl and sony_effio_support.stl
    • Special instruction
    1) Video mount is using two files, one for video mount and the other one to reduce the hole of top plate of the qav250.
    2) For camera mount, I used a 3mm screw as an axis
    3) Support transfo is only used to if you want to put step down voltage regulator, be carefull not to use a voltage regulator which produce to much heat.
    4) You should drill 2 small hole to fix the back light to the frame, and two other other hole to fixe the qav250 light to this support

J'ai conçus ces supports pour régler l'horizontalité du plateau.
J'utilise sur ma µdelta un miroir de 15cm de coté (à 3 francs 6 sous dans tous magasin de bricolage)
Après avoir monté les supports et avoir laissé les vis de réglage dévissées, commencez par calibrer la hauteur comme d'habitude.
Je vous conseil de faire un essaie en imprimant un disque de grand diamètre et de fine épaisseur.
Lors de l'impression, le coté le plus fin est celui qui n'aura pas besoin d'être réglé. Pour avoir une impression homogène, vissez les vis des autres supports (qui vont remonter le bord du plateau qui en a besoin) afin d'obtenir une épaisseur constante.
Il est possible que lors de ce réglage d'horizontalité du plateau vous ayez besoin de recalibrer la hauteur.
J'espère que cette « notice » est suffisamment explicite, sinon je rajouterais des photos et schéma.

Après avoir imprimé 3 support, vissez dans le trou de la partie la plus épaisse une vis de M3 (10mm de long mini). Puis glissez les support autour du miroir. pour finir vissez les support au plateau de l'imprimante en utilisant les trous d'origine.

Printed .3 layer height. Mounted using velcro straps through slits in hood. Place a cut piece of glue stick in the circular hole in the top. I mounted GPS via 3mm nylon screws and nuts/standoffs.

I didn't like the six-way header pin connector used for the hotends. I found the pins would keep sliding back through the plastic, so instead I decided to switch to using 9-pin D-type connectors.  
This part attaches a connector just below the extruder so the entire hotend connection (bowden tube and electrical wiring) is connected in once place - at the extruder.

Print out three copies. Attach a D-type connector using two M3 bolts and nuts. Attach to the extruder using the existing M3 bolts either side of the bowden tube hole. I used the following pinout: Pin 1 - Thermistor
Pin 2 - Thermistor
Pin 3 - no connection
Pin 4 - Fan +12V
Pin 5 - Fan GND
Pins 6/7 - Heater cartridge
Pins 8/9 - Heater cartridge Or you could use a 15-pin VGA connector for more signals such as for cooling fans.

comments.text: I also didn't like the connectors on my RRP. Upgraded it last night to use this (just for one printhead -- I have the others disconnected right now). Works great; I love the idea, and the DB9 is just easier to deal with. Thank you for this!

Every evening before bedtime I read my daughter a good night story. As she gets older the stories become longer and it gets sometimes hard to remember which story we already read. So I decided to make us a bookmark. We both love Disney and so I designed this simple Mickey Mouse shaped bookmark. It is really fast and easy to print and with PLA's resiliency also very durable.

Print with bendable filament like PLA!  
Three Perimeters make it durable.   
Use a top- / bottom-infill pattern of of your choice, but make it solid on every layer in between. As this model is only 2mm thick, you have 10 solid layers with 0.2mm layer-height.

comments.text: This is an awesome bookmark!  We have tried so many different bookmark designs on Thingiverse, and this is one of the better ones.  I'm not sure if I will be able to keep this one away from my daughter.  I might just have to make another one for her.  :)

title: RCExplorer canopy enhancement pack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Enhancement pack for the rcexplorer.se canopy for the tricopter mini. Skids
Rear spacer base for level installation
2.3mm spacer (for original canopy rear spacer holder)
Non-conductive board camera mount
Antenna mount (holds 3mm plastic bowden tube) For more room for the lipo:
Nose spacer 8mm off-set
Nose spacer 10mm off-set
8mm spacer
10mm spacer
12.3mm spacer

Print all parts from ABS, 0.1 layer height, solid. For the Non-conductive board camera mount:
Drill holes to 2.5mm and use a M3 thread tapping tool to cut threads into the mount. If possible use M3x20 screws to secure the mount. For the spacers you will need longer screws than supplied by RCExplorer.se as the screws need to be longer to get a good grip on the original 40mm spacers. I'd recommend cutting M5 (inner diameter 3mm) aluminium tubes to length instead of printing the spacers. For the antenna mounts: Use M3 plastic tube and feed the antennas through the tube to protect them from the propellers. Use CA to glue the mounts to the side panels. If using a GoPro, make sure that the antennas do not get into the view of the camera.

title: Nema 23 Bowden Extruder swivel mount for DaVinci

description.text:
Once upon a time I had under-extrusion issues with my DaVinci printer. Now I have an Nema 23 Bowden feed Extruder :)  
This is a remix of the original Nema 17 swivel mount (which was a remix of another bigger one) the point of which is to have as short a bowden tube as possible to reduce ooze.  
The bearing in the bottom is from a skateboard. I don't encourage sabotage, by teenagers look very funny scraping along the ground on only 3 wheels, it takes them ages to work out what is wrong!

Print with about 50% fill as it takes a bit of strain when you push it together.  
Press the bearing into the plastic with a vice, it should be a tight fit.

Most mobile phones don't have forward-facing flashes, and the forward-facing cameras are not very sensitive to light. Taking selfies in bad lighting is difficult or impossible. This clip-on flash mirror reflects the flash on the phone's backside and allows it to light selfies.  
To use this (at least on Android 5), turn your camera into selfie mode, drag down from the top of the screen twice to get to the quick settings, and tap the flashlight button to turn on the flashlight.

First, adapt the size of the whole widget, and the size of the cutoff for the phone, to your phone's size. In the OpenSCAD file, these are the two variables: size = 4;
phoneThickness = 0.7; Once printed out, cover the inside of the object with a reflective material like aluminium foil, bits of reflective metal, or small mirrors. You might want to wrap the two nubs that grab the phone with isolation tape, to give them a little it more grip.

This is a plate to convert a Nema 23 mount to a Nema 17 plate. It allows you to mount a cheap chinese metal extruder meant for a Nema 17 onto a Nema 23. You have to drill out the extruder gear with a 6mm drill (and wiggle it, the shaft is actually 6.35) but if you have a spring loaded extruder it doesn't matter if it is a little eccentric. The Nema 23 has huge torque compared to a Nema 17, typically Nema 17 have 10 - 50 Ncm torque (0.1Nm - 0.5Nm) whereas a Nema 23 is measured in whole Nm usually between 1Nm - 5Nm (100Ncm - 500Ncm) so basically 10 times as much power (yay!) I would be telling a lie if I said I never had motor slip now, but it only happens if I do something stupid (usually too thin a first layer as I cram it into the plate to get adhesion!) but otherwise? No, never :) anyway, I "only" have 1.26Nm motor from ebay that cost £16.50! The mounts to the Nema 23 are M5, the mounts to the Nema 17 are M3. I found I had to turn the nuts and bolts upside-down (e.g. bolts push through from bottom)
I printed it 50% fill as I am mean, probably should be 100%

remixed_from.author: dagnall53
remixed_from.title: Self contained servo coupler for G scale trains

title: Revised G Scale LGB Servo Coupling

description.text:
UPDATE: After using this for a while I have noticed that setting the engaged and uncouple positions on the servos is very critical. If the servo is too far "engaged", (ie pulled "back" ) then the hook cannot spring down to couple easily. Also, if the Unlock position was too far "forward", then the hook on the carriage could get caught behind the front part of the pusher.
To overcome this, I have modified the design by removing the front of the pusher entirely. I then modified the hook, to keep its geometry when engaged roughly the same. (see new file "hook3" ). Without the front bar of the pusher it now disengages very reliably. (see "mk3 pusher"). The original reason for the front part of the pusher was to provide a removable lip to keep the hook of the carriage engaged, but with the hook from the loco engaging in the carriage, there seems little point in this, so I removed it and will see how well it works on the track. It certainly decouples very easily and the "engaged" servo position now seems much less critical.
Please send feedback if you have any improvements. video with full design working decoupling from a carriage (servos set correctly!) ... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UJGuc5AQuE4 The parts Loop2 Pusher2 and Base2 are very slight modifications on the original (still available in the 123D file) based on my building the first "production run".. I have found that it now works well with the same magnets in the loop and hook - so you can use 3 mm dia * 4 mm long magnets in both parts. The Mk3 version also uses this larger magnet This is a complete revision of my earlier (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:398423) and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:377751 couplings. The main benefit is that the hook is now free to move in the horizontal axis, which should make the coupler work better around corners. I have also revised the servo's housing, and it now allows space for the wires connected at the bottom!. The new magnets hold the hook firmly in the centre , "engaged" position, but allow the hook to engage with another carriage when they are pushed together, and completely replaces the difficult to adjust springs in previous versions.
As the pusher pushes forwards, the pivot pushes forwards and tilts down, pulling the hook away from loop and de-coupling..

Make with 0.2 layer height, and 0.4 mm nozzle if possible.
I have revised the space for the servo, but be very careful with swarf and blobs near the gears as there is very little room. I use a file to clear this out.
The servo should fit with its front two legs under the triangular retainers. The rear is held in place with a 0.5 mm steel wire. The picture shows how this all fits.
The sliding parts of the pusher and loop have been made so they can be easily cleaned out and smoothed with a 1.5 5 mm flat modellers file.
Cut out the 8 mm hole in the "loop", as well as clearing out the slot for the connecting screw towards the back. (these were filled and have thin closures to help the underside print better) drill out the 1.8 mm clearance holes and the 0.5mm holes in the base. Drill out the 3mm holes for the magnets.
The dimensions at the back upper part of the hook are critical.. If the back is too high, the decoupler will jam (the servo has very little force).. But if too low, the hook may drop right down to the track when decoupling and will derail the train as it catches the sleepers. I put three different versions in the hooks options for printing, but I found printing the one with a slight slope worked best, but filing to get best motion is probably essential.
It was originally designed to so the magnets should just release the hook to drop under gravity as the pusher is slid forwards. However after building two with the slightly chamfered back to the hook I found it very nicely forces the hook down. But pre assembly, filing for smoothness and testing before fitting is essential.
Assembly to the train is a fiddle especially locating the servo in the base properly, but i would recommend having the servo connected to a servo tester, so you can easily move the servo drive lug to align it with the hole in the pusher. Pre assembly and testing before fitting to the train is essential.
When fitting the train, assemble the pusher in the loop, and connect to the loco using the original LGB coupling screw fitted through the slot hole in the loop. The squarish hole in the pusher allows you access to the screw. The LGB loco will probably have a 8 mm peg that fits in the hole you should have cleared in the pusher. Hold the whole thing together with 1.7 10mm pan head cross head screws (the hole in the base is sized to allow a 3.2 mm cross head screwdriver to fit these). If you forget the 8mm hole, the whole assembly will be angled down and will not work properly. Also be careful that the train centre buffer does not distort the main loop. My Stainz rear buffer slightly distorted the rear loop and stopped the pusher working. I filed the buffer to correct this.
Following my tests I modified the files slightly to correct some slight issues, (2) There is now a second "loop" file with different mesh-mixer designed supports to make printing easier.

comments.text:
I used "1.5 g Servo Micro Linear Servos" . You can see it clearly in one of the photos.
There are many around, and have both "left" and "right" types. The design can take either.
Note that the body has tiny undercuts to locate and hold the PCB at the "gear" end of the servo, and a wire part through the body holds down the "opposite end.
You may need to cut the very top of the "horn" to stop it hitting the body. (should be obvious when you test build it).
I bought most from Ebay. But Hobby king also have them and I have bought some from there.
I have not done any tests to see if there are differences in power or strength.

title: Kossel Hexagonal Heated Bed Glass Holder / Glass Clamp

description.text:
I've always had problems with glass slippage on my kossels.
This solves it. It clamps on the heated bed, and allows no movement
of glass. Print qty 3 of these. There designed to print with the slot upwards, so no worry of support. I print mine solid. I found infill makes them want to break. There under alot of stress when you crank down the bolts. My Heated Bed:
http://www.aliexpress.com/item/NEW-3-D-printer-Delta-rostock-hexagon-round-heat-bed-MK3-reference/32227244056.html?spm=2114.01020208.3.132.kJ2z7X&ws_ab_test=201407_2,201444_5,201409_5

You need qty 2 M5 bolts, and qty 2 nuts per side. Total of 3 sides.
Print solid, then insert bolts and nuts. Place on bed with glass in position and make sure the glass is cornered. Print in ABS, as PLA will soften at max heated bed temp.

This is my version of a nice racing drone though for begginers who keep crashing all the time. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xnum6L-rfKQ&feature=youtu.be Features:
Low CDG - GoPro and batteries have been lowered to the middle plate. This also helps protecting the battery in the event of crash. Arms have been designed in order to minimize the chances of breaking the motors.
If hitting the ground heavily, the arm should break through the weak point that can be observed in the pictures. Normally, when this happens, the motor starts to hang arround being held by only these weak conection points that attach the cable that comes from the esc to the motor.
I had one already broken due to this. To avoid it, two clamps on each arm hold the cables.
When breaking trough the weak point, the cover of the cable will help to absorve all the tension, avoiding the chance of breaking the conections. Shock-absorbing landing gears 10º down-tilted fpv camera mount.

Electronics used on this dessign; Emax 2204 motors - 2300KV
Emax 10A esc's
GensAce 1300 mAh 25C power battery
Tiger 480 mAh 25C fpv battery
CC3D openpilot flight control board
Stock power distribution board
Stock 700 TVL fpv camera
GoPro hero 3 black+ camera and cover
5030 propellers. Compatible up to 6030 props.
Stock buzzer
Boscam 600mW fpv video transmitter

Here you can find a selection of tutorials and explanations that are really usefull for all those who are new to the hobby -General Quadcopter tutorials (really good): https://www.youtube.com/user/Painless360 -PID (basic understanding): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LtocGBngSrA -PID (in detail explanation): http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showpost.php?p=25977521&postcount=5 -PID tuning for hold-altitude mode (multiwii): https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/80566205/not%20remove/tutorials/PID%20Alt%20Hold.html -Multiwii general wiki: http://www.multiwii.com/wiki/index.php?title=Main_Page#Software

comments.text: your FPV cam is pointed down should be pointed up.  interesting design.  but your mock up looks off with 2 video transmitters on top.
comments.author: nospel

comments.text:
From your comment I guess you didn't read the description.
It's a design focused to people starting on the hobby. These people won't go as fast as to tilt the drone enough, so that you need to point the camera up. Instead, it's better to point it down to keep the visibility of the ground clear as they are flying higher.
comments.author: nospel

comments.text: yes i read the description as starter.  this is where we will disagree if starting out should be flying line of sight and not FPV lean to fly first.  if you are going to fly would say point the camera straight ahead so you keep orientation if you are nose up or down.  When you fly you are looking for what is in front of you unless checking for you crash landing location.   I have been flying RC since 98, airplane, helicopter, and multi rotor, and FPV.   As far as buzzer to monitor batteries any one i ever tried was never heard while flying.  Telemetry works but most of the time i fly with a straight timer.
comments.author: Ipi

comments.text:
Well, the design is made for people new to the hobby, like me.
I feel more comfortable having the camera pointing down. It's easier to see the home point as you fly higher but not faster, while still being able to see the horizon (fish eye lens). Also the tilting is just 10 degree, which is not much. As for the buzzer, I can hear it well because I don't fly so far away. If someone doesn't like it, it can always be removed.
comments.author: nospel

comments.text: I like the design.

title: Spoolholder with mount for 2020 Extrusion I-Type 5

description.text:
Recommends: I'll recommend you take a look at my new
Flat Filament Spool Holder - No spring- The Claw remake.

I needed a new Spoolholder for my version of "Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D printer" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:811271 and a way to mount it filament spool to my Extrusions and created this one.

I used the "low-friction-um2-spoolholder" https://www.youmagine.com/designs/low-friction-um2-spoolholder as my source, but ended up changing everything. Everything is slimmed down, reinforced and basically reinvented even though they look pretty much the same at a glance.

My build does away with the center spacer and instead inserts the Bearings from either end. It makes for much stronger parts and eliminates the risk of pushing out the ends of the pieces if you overtighten them. The finger nut has been slimmed down to make a less obtrusive part. The inner spoolholder have had some finger-knobs added to ease the tightening/loosening action. Edit: 7th april 2016
Updated instructions here.
In the files you basically find 2 models, where I consider the first model as deprecated - I keep it as the source
Deprectated files:
reinforced_center_threadding_for_spoolholder_608zz_226mm.stl
reinforced_base_with_fingergrib_for_spoolholder608zz_226mm.stl Edit: 7. september 2015:
Added a version of the mount without middle and side-guides. Works the same and I recommend printing with 100% infill (for the mount). Added final version of the "slimmed nut" Added 3 spacers which you might want to use between the Nut which goes against the Mount and between the base in order to reduce friction slightly. If you use a locking nut, you want to use the 5mm version. Edit the 13th september 2015
I added 2 new models where the Base and *Center parts are combined into 1: inner part 6mm-basehole.stl and inner part 15mm-basehole.stl The difference in the two parts
The depth of the hole in the base, facing your printer: One is 6mm deep, intended for your bearing to sit in there with 1mm going outside to make a bit of space between the base and the printer. The other part has 15mm hole intented for both the bearing and an M8 nut if that fits your build

Printer:

JennyPrinter

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

100

Notes: Do print with same infill percentage or they will tend to get either awfully tight or Loose.
  • Do yourself a favor and make the mount 100% infill. Or at least high.
  • The other parts can be 25% infill with 3 perimeter lines and arond 1mm top/bottom
  • I printed with 0,2mm layer height.

You need to print 1 of the 2 following pieces:
  • One is 6mm deep, intended for your bearing to sit in there with 1mm going outside to make a bit of space between the base and the printer. "inner-part-6mm_basehole.stl"
  • The other part has 15mm hole intented for both the bearing and an M8 nut if that fits your build: "inner-part-15mm_basehole.stl"
    • Also need to print
    slimmed_spoolholder_nut.stl Might want to print
    I have included 2 Mount pieces I have used on my extrusion printer.
  • The "guides" version have "guides" on the sides to grib the sides of a 20x20 extrusion piece Mount_for_Spoolholder-With-M8nut.stl
  • The other Mount can be used with any printer, but you might want to just make a hole in your case or find another option: "mount_without_guides_for_spoolholder-with-m8nut.stl"
  • Various spacers etc are just in case you need some spacers. They are not mandatory in any way
    • Assembling
    Bearings goes into either end of the assembly and a spacer is not needed between, as it was from the source.

description.header: Do not use mixed infill rates
description.text:
Print the parts with the same fill-rate or you are going to have problems fitting them together.
You can see how I had to grib my middle-threadded part with some tool, as I printed it in 100% and it had to be worked a bit (a lot) to fit properly with my end nut, which was 25% Holes are 22,6mm to make it easier to "install" the 608ZZ bearings. My 100% infill middle part had a loose fit for the bearing, but 1 piece of insulation tape around the bearing made that issue go away - minor issue in any case. Support
You might need some support if you print the Mount with middle and side guides. M8 nuts
There is room for an M8 locking nut in the mounting piece, but I guess a normal M8 nut would work as well (since the normal type is smaller).

2x M8 locking nuts. (you can use normal M8 nuts)
1x M8 normal nut.
Some 8mm threadded rod.
2x 608ZZ bearings. Using these for Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D printer
If you are going to Mount 2 filament rolls you need at least one of the mounts to be without guides, or there is not enough room for them vertically.

author: dintid

description.text:
Dieses System verhindert effektiv, dass der Boden neben und unter dem Fressnapf verschmutzt wird oder schaden nimmt. In der Mitte ein Food-Bowl.stl und acht Plain.stl drumherum.  
Bitte unbedingt Lebensmittelechtes Filament benutzen, damit sich keine Schadstoffe im Katzenfutter lösen. Alternativ kann man auch ein Ring.stl drucken und einen konventionellen Fressnapf einsockeln. So kommt das Futter nicht direkt mit dem Kunststoff in berührung.  
Die Cup.stl eignen sich hervorragend, um kleine Köstlichkeiten darin zu plazieren. Die meißten Katzen haben spaß daran, sie mit der Pfote herauszuholen.

This system prevents your cat from dropping it's food on the floor beneath the food-bowl. Just print one food-bowl.stl und eight plain.stl around it.  
Please use foodsave filament so that no toxic substances can get into the catfood. If you have no such plastic just print one ring.stl and put a regular feeding bowl in it. In this way, the food doesn't get in contact with the plastic.  
The cup.stl is perfect for putting little treats inside. Most cats have a lot of fun by getting them out with their paws.

description.text:
Needed a mount for my filament spoolholder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1000323 and came up with this design. Edit: 8. september 2015:
Added a mount based on the one without guide, with rounded top edges. Purely visual changes. Edit: 7. september 2015:
Added a mount without the middle and sideguides.

Do yourself a favor and make it 100% infill. Or at least high. I printed with 0,2mm layer height. The mount with middle and side guides might need support when printing. There is room for an M8 locking nut in the mounting piece, but I guess a normal M8 nut would work as well (since the normal type is smaller). BOM:
2x M8 locking nuts. OR 2x M8 normal nut. (I recommend locking nuts)
Some 8mm threadded rod depending on your need.
2x M3 screws and 2x T-nuts to fix the mount to the 2020 extrusion Using these for Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D printer:
At least one of the mounts must be without guides, or there is not enough room for them.

mount your e3d v6 all metal hot end to your taz 4 or equivelant model with my modified design that makes sure everything is perfect! this was modified from the matterhackers website because theirs made the extruder too high for the bed. Mine was printed in PET, but you may use abs or whatever you like, this design works flawless.

after printing two locks and one base .stl's you must clamp the two together on the extruder and drill the 4 holes for bolts, once you have the holes insert the screws from the top and tighten the nuts on the bottom. the base then gets sandwiched between the extruder mount and the carriage. This mod allows you to use the e3d hot end without changing bed or anything else.

This spool dispenser is designed to let your printer easily pull filament without jamming. The swivelling turn-table on the bottom will let the printer pull the spool into the direction with the least resistance, and the rollers on top will let the spool easily dispense its filament. This design will work with the MakerBot Large and XL spools, and will probably work with most other brands. This design is 100% 3D-printable, and is designed to have almost zero supports. It is intentionally designed to have thick components so that the whole thing can be printed at a low infill setting without losing strength. This design still needs some work. Here are a few of the things to come: -Some beautification.
-An actual picture! (the print is in progress now)
-A file that has all of the parts laid out and MakerBot ready

Step 1: Print everything; you will need one of everything except the ball and bearing files. You will need six balls and four bearings.  
Step 2: Place the six balls into the base.  
Step 3: Snap the swivel-top on over the base and balls; it should move freely.  
Step 4: Put one bearing on each of the posts on the dispenser sides, then plug each of the posts into their respective slots on the center brace.  
Step 5: Plug the dispenser assembly (the thing you just made in step 4) into the base assembly (the thing you made in step 2 and 3).  
Step 6: Put your filament vertically onto the dispenser, with the working end of your filament coming through the bottom.  
Step 7: Grab yourself a cup of coffee and a piece of pecan pie-you're done!

title: Effecteur magnetique pour HotEnd Merlin - Magnetic effector for Merlin HotEnd

description.header: !!!! Nouvelle version ici / New version here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2024371

description.text:
Effecteur magnétique avec conduit de ventilation conçu pour une HotEnd Merlin
Conception réalisée avec : Autodesk Fusion 360
Lien vers l'assemblage : http://a360.co/1FrkNPn NB : Les pièces sont conçues pour être imprimées sans support matériel. Effecteur : conçu pour une liaison magnétique avec les bras, il reçoit six aimants d'un diamètre extérieur de 12mm. L’entraxe entre les aimants est de 40mm, ce qui assure la compatibilité avec les imprimantes Kossel et autres deltas utilisant ce même entre-axe. Conduit de ventilation : Conçu pour recevoir un ventilateur de 40x40mm, le flux d'air est scindé en deux pour refroidir le ColdEnd d'une part (conduit d'amenée du filament à la chambre de fusion) et l'impression d'autre part. Mâchoire de serrage : elle est conçue pour bloquer fermement le HotEnd Merlin (ou tout autre modèle dont la bague supérieure aurait des dimensions identiques - voir schémas). Le blocage est réalisé par serrage de la mâchoire contre l'effecteur au moyen de deux vis M3. Il y a la possibilité d'utiliser deux écrous, mais le vissage dans le plastique est normalement largement suffisant. Conseil : Si vous imprimez cet effecteur en PLA (ce qui est aussi mon cas), lors de son utilisation n'oubliez pas de le ventiler en permanence afin d'éviter sa surchauffe et donc sa déformation (paramètre a positionner au niveau du slicer)

Magnetic effector with fan duct designed for Merlin HotEnd
Design made with Autodesk Fusion 360
Link to the design : http://a360.co/1FrkNPn NB : parts are designed to be printed without material supports Effector: designed for magnetic connection with the arms, it receives six magnets having an outer diameter of 12mm. The center distance between the magnets is 40 mm, which ensures compatibility with Kossel printers and any other delta using this same center distance. Fan duct : Designed to receive a 40x40mm fan, the air flow is split in two for cooling the ColdEnd (filament supply pipe to the melting chamber) and the printing. Jaw: it is designed to securely lock the Merlin HotEnd (or any model with the upper ring has the same dimensions - see diagrams). Blocking is performed by clamping the jaw against the end-effector with two screws M3. There is the possibility of using two nuts, but screwing into plastic is normally good enough. Tip: If you print this effector with PLA (which is my case) when in use, be sure to always ventilate it in order to avoid overheating and thus its deformation. (it's a slicer parameter)

description.text: Generic DIN rail mount for a DC-DC converter.  Hole is sized for a #4 thread cutting screw.  Enjoy.

I wanted to design a spool holder that I could operate with one hand and was different. This is that!
This works with Spools with ø44 mm I.D.s and up.The wheels turn on the inside of the spool.The elephant ears guide the spool on its smooth edge and clicks into place.It adjusts for wider spools.
I drilled and screwed the dove tail mount to the acrylic frame of my Prusa i3 (M4 x 20 pan heads). I will work on another mount later. For axles on the wheels, I used a wooden skewer from the dollar store, and on the other side I used a piece of a coat hanger, which I cut with Pliers. You can also use 2 round toothpicks but you will need to secure them in place

Clean and sand Spool holder so dovetail can be inserted cleanly into mount. Make sure axles fit easily thru wheels. You may have to scale them up depending on your printer.
Cut axles to length , using skewers. toothpicks, coat hanger wire, something approx 2.7mm. for the axles.Navigate axles into holder and thru wheels.
Slide the assembled holder on the dovetailed mount.
Put Spool on mount.
.Insert and slide in Elepha-adjuster to maintain a small amount of clearance to your spool.
I made this using SketchUp and Blender and more imagination than skill.This is version 6.

description.text: A simple retainer plate for a $2 well nut. You can use the existing holes on the platform, you don't need to drill or thread anything -- this was the simplest approach I could find/think. Also, the rubber should act as a spring, which is nice (I guess). I have one of the new aluminium platforms, so previous fixes needed modification. Credit for this approach (which was the simplest I found) goes to http://www.soliforum.com/topic/2341/poor-mans-antibacklash-nut-no-assembly-required/, but the new platform has nothing there to jam the nut against, so I made this retainer plate. Backlash on the new platform was minimal, but it was there. This seems to eliminate it nicely. We'll see how well the rubber holds over time (but for $2... who cares :). Update 11/9/13 Added observations, after about six months of use, into instructions.

• Move platform down so you can work (not much space for fingers back there, tweezers and pliers might help a bit too).
  • Screw well nut onto Z-axis rod. Manually push the platform up slightly to eliminate backlash and, holding it there, tighten well nut.
  • Place retainer plate over well nut and fasten with screws and nuts to pre-drilled (unused) holes on platform. M3 should work, although I had some 4-40s at hand.
  • Might want to dab some extra lithium grease (rubber will initially wipe off some grease).
    • Note that you have to insert the well rubber nut brim downwards (not up, as in the forum post). In this orientation, the rubber might also work as a spring. My Z-rod is just the right length (<1mm shorter and the nut would start coming off when Z-axis is homed -- wheww!) Works nicely so far. PS. The screw holes have a countersink, because the 4-40 screws I had were a bit short. You can edit SCAD source if you're worried about strength.

• Based on reports from other people, it seems that not all rods have equal length. If yours is too short for the depicted installation, you're out of luck, sorry.

  • After about six months of use, it seems that my original theory on how this works was off. I install the well nut by tightening. The idea was that this would make the rubber work like a compression spring. However, observations do not entirely agree with this.

    Tightening the nut makes the rubber bulge a bit (btw, you don't need a wrench--actually, you can overtighten to the point of binding the axis even with fingers, so be careful). It seems this makes the rod threads "bite" into the rubber, which is what removes the backlash. Since the rubber is compliant, the axis won't bind. However, there are still stresses on the rubber which, over long period of time, will make the nut come loose (you can observe this if you mark the original alignment of nut and retainer with a permanent marker).

    As the nut loosens: (i) the bulge will diminish, making it slightly less effective at reducing backlash, and (ii) the rubber base will expand in height, creating stresses that after months may crack the retaining plate at it's thinnest part.

    I currently deal with this by just re-installing the nut every few months (works for me..). Other idea: instead of tightening the nut, leave it a bit loose (and tighten plate instead) to make it work like an extension spring instead (hopefully). I haven't tried this, and I have my doubts if the rubber (esp. at the base) is rigid enough to make this work. If you do, please describe experience in comments.

    I've also uploaded a modified plate (v2) which should be stronger and hopefully last even longer (currently testing, will update with observations in a few months). The plate also has fixed hole placement (X-distance was off by 0.5mm in original) and I'm now using 8mm M3 screws, with washers.

  • Combined with the periodic Z-wobble "bandaid" in firmware, the overall results are pretty darn good! Note, however, that you will need to collect measurements with the laser pointer jig -- a dial gauge + gauge mount does not have the necessary precision (after a fresh well nut installation, the wobble is in the order of a few microns).

description.text:
If you're like me, received one of these printers recently... Then you may have noticed that they come with a laser cut spool holder (which isn't worth $0.02 IMHO) and with only 1 spool holder for the back. So running 2 colors at once is basically impossible straight out of the box.  
So I contacted the company that manufactures them, and they sent me the .slt files for the original spool holders for the BACK of the machine. If nothing else, it can at lease plug the holes right?  
Anyway, here it is. Prints 3 nuts, and one spool holder on one plate. Have fun!  
EDIT 9/12/15 : Added the 3D printable files for the laser cut spool roller feet that come with the printer. 
EDIT 12/2/2015 : Added the Spool alone, without the nuts.
EDIT 1/16/2016 : Added a single Nut File for those of you needing to print only one nut.
EDIT 12/15/2015 : Added the nuts alone.

I built mine with ReplicatorG & Skeinforge with these settings : .2 Layer Height
25% Infill (Could do more if you want)
2 Shells

comments.text:
I don't mean to disparage the project as I've been using it until I got a proper holder design.
The issues I have with this:use of supports is very troublesome in MakerBot Desktop, the layers are parallel to the shearing force (two PLA prints broke), takes a long time to print and requires cooling and/or slow speed. Hopefully I won't offend anyone, I made a design in two parts that takes less time to print and is more sturdy: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2543519
As a bonus, it allows "quick-changing" spools, if you're into that thing, and clamping onto most surfaces, including the spool holes.

title: Lulzbot TAZ Bulldog Extruder Mount Version 2 (Version 1 Deprecated)

description.text:
UPDATE 11/26/15 : ADDED TAZ_BULLDOG_MOUNT_VER_2.stl. and TAZ_BULLDOG_FAN_MOUNT.stl.
This is an update to the original design. The following has been added to Version 2.
1) Fan wire hole added to the right side.
2) Added screw mount holes for fan on front. I use this duct fan mounting arm: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:540716 and this additional attachment TAZ_BULLDOG_FAN_MOUNT.stl.
3) Widened the area where the hot end fits to accommodate D3r hot ends.
4) Added round ends to lessen warpage. These are to be removed prior to used. Enable and simplify your Lulzbot TAZ printing with the Bulldog all metal extruder. This print is very straight forward and installation is easy. This extruder, when using the AO Hex hot end, is about 10 grams less than the current TAZ extruder. The Bulldog comes with a pretty nifty hot end cooling fan assembly. There were clearance issues and unfortunately I could not find a way to get it to work well, so that is why I have created this model which embeds the fan into the mount itself. Im currently tweaking this model but this version works fine. See change/problem list below. See the Jude Labs construction video on Youtube:
https://youtu.be/eE2fWvsYDnw Current Update List for version 1 (removed from Thingiverse):
1) Add fan wire hole
2) Add screw mount holes for fan (version one still works without)
3) Make Prettier
4) When using the AO Hexagon hotend, the Z axis of the mount assembly is very low and the ZStop has to be very very low. Also there could be interference between the mount assembly and the heated bed mounts. Working on a way to extend the hot end length to the normal TAZ height.
5) Center to the Nozzle so that no configurations changes need to be made between this Extruder mount and the TAZ extruder mount. When using the Bulldog mount, the nozzle is off the bed slightly on the left X axis.

YOUTUBE Walkthrough:
https://youtu.be/MeO4IKU9B64 New Settings:
With this extruder you will need to reset your Estep to 500. Print Settings:
Material: ABS
Nozzle: .5mm
Layer Height: .4mm TAZ to Bulldog Wiring:
There is a bit of confusion on the wiring since the Bulldog stepper uses a different wiring schema than what comes with a TAZ stepper. The Bulldog that I got had no instructions at all. BULLDOG TAZ
RED A+ RED
PURPLE A- BLUE
BLUE B+ GREEN
YELLOW B- BLACK

18650 to 2 D Cell Adapter

This adapter is for 2 D cell flashlights. This adapts a single 18650 battery to replace 2 D cells. Print two of every thing for a 4 cell flashlight. Extra parts needed:
  • 1 penny for negative end
  • 4 1/8"x 62mm dowels or plastic rods
  • 5" of 14ga stranded wire
    • Instructions for assembly:
  • Strip back 1/2" of insulation. Push through bottom piece. Then flair out the strands.
  • Take penny and insert into bottom of the piece. You will need a pair of pliers to seat the penny against the flared out wire. See photo #3.
  • The top piece is two pieces. Super glue the part without holes onto the second piece. Use a battery to line up the hole for the battery.
  • Remove battery after glue has activated.
  • Now slide wire through hole and cut the extra off. Pull wire back out and strip back 1/2" of insulation. Slide wire back through hole in top piece. Cut away any wire strands that prevent wire from laying flat in bottom of the hole. See photo #2.
  • Now super glue ends of dowels and press into top until they bottom out.
  • Place several drops of glue on the dowel ends. Then press the bottom piece onto the dowels. Be sure they are flush with the bottom of the bottom piece.
  • Push the 18650 battery into hole on top firmly setting the battery against the flared out wire.
  • The overall length from positive to the negative end should be 120mm.
    Test for continuity.

description.text: Let me start by saying that this ArmDrive Bowden Extruder setup is one of the best Bowden driven system I have personally tried.  It's so simple, yet very reliable and effective.  Even though the designer tried to beef up the filament entry guide, PLA is still very rough and it will still wear down eventually. description.text: Fully enclosed case, designed to house a pi 2, boost charger, LiPo battery, and a couple modules. I designed this case to accommodate the following parts: Boost charger (combined with a rechargeable battery, is an UPS) https://www.adafruit.com/products/2465 Lithium Ion Polymer Battery - 3.7v 2500mAh - that fits right under the pi, https://www.adafruit.com/products/328 There are 3 ports, one for charging/powering the unit via micro USB. The Pi micro USB is blocked off and unused, this micro USB is part of the 1000C charge/boost module. The other 2 ports are for the on/off switch - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007QAJMHO?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00 and the OLED screen - SSD1306 SPI OLED 128x64 generic screen I got on ebay a couple years ago for a few bucks. You will probably need to modify the OLED port to conform to your particular display module, or remove the port for a headless setup. there are screw mounts and holes for the boost charger and the pi, and the battery cavity is also a tight fit. The entire design has minimal space in mind while keeping everything enclosed. It fits (I should say almost fits) in the palm of most peoples' hands. I used FreeCAD and the source files are included. This was initially for my handheld GPS system I made, that works excellently, and if you want more information, such as the 4GB image, I may be able to beam it over to you if you PM me, we can arrange that. In time I may re-use it for other handheld instruments or even some automobile related projects like lojack or data logging, head units, etc. ECU for UAVs, the possibilities are endless. The quad core Pi2 is a credit card size little monster, and its capabilities open up so many opportunities. I just wish it had some sort of ADC as well, but you can't have your cake and eat it too I guess.

This is a complete 3D printed small parts set for a DIY bio filter. You will also need a Danner Mag drive pump 300-500 GPH, some PVC fittings, some nuts and bolts, a trash can, gasket material and some filter media. I recommend using real filter media and not the shotgun wadding show in the pictures. Most of these parts have been uploaded but this is just a convenient set with pictures. Included in the printed parts is a .5 inch screen for the pump out flow. This will replace the PVC with holes that is in the picture (inside the trashcan where the pump sends water). It does not require supports to print when properly oriented. Also included are a few optional parts such as a smaller two part screen and a slip to thread adapter. You can use the two part 4x4 1.5” screen for both the drain and filter outflow instead of the small round one shown in the pictures as the drain screen. I also recommend silicone-ing the last elbow before it goes into the trash can. That way if you ever have to take the pump off you can just redo the silicone and clip it back into its mount. This is an improved filter design on an older design that had the pump inside the trashcan under the filter media. With the pump being external it’s much easier to get going if the pump ever seizes. These magnetic driven pumps are extremely efficient but require a small burst of energy to get spinning and will regularly require a light tap to assist it in starting. Assembly is pretty straight forward and is show in the pictures. If you have any problems feel free to leave a comment and I’ll try to help. Pump:
http://www.amazon.com/Danner-02525-Pond-Pump-18-Foot/dp/B0002564LW/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1441477093&sr=8-2&keywords=danner+pump
Gasket material:
http://www.amazon.com/Neoprene-Sheet-Gasket-Black-Thick/dp/B0075ZMFME/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1441477126&sr=8-3&keywords=neoprene+sheet
Filter media:
http://www.amazon.com/Aquaponics-Aquaculture-Hydroponics-Garden-Supply/dp/B00UPSAL7Y/ref=sr_1_13?ie=UTF8&qid=1441477197&sr=8-13&keywords=filter+media Any Trashcan will Work Get nuts and bolts that fit the pump mounting bracket You can find all these parts at other locations for cheaper. These

description.text:
I had some filament without spool and needed one that can be quickly done. Thus I decided to create a very minimalistic one myself. You just need a few M3x16-mm-screws, washers and nuts. The inner tube sits strong in the ring, if not, you can glue the two rings.  
The spool is not super strong, but it doesn't need to. I Just printed it with 35% infill and 0.4 mm walls with PLA/PHA.If anything breaks I will do it again with stronger walls and more infill. But it seems it's quite good already.   
It fits on the original UMO spool holder, but it's larger than the normal spools and keeps the filament a lot less bent.

title: Universal Spool Holder with ball bearings

description.text:
Universal spool holder with two ball bearings.
It can fit any spool size, width is adjustable. "Fast change!" between spools, little friction while it spins. It is componed of:
  • Two horizontal printed parts (part1 and part2)
  • Two 608zz ball bearings that fits exactly into part1 and part2
  • One horizontal 8mm threaded bar and 4 (or 2) 8mm nuts
  • One m6x100 hex bolt with a wing nut to keep everthing together
    • That's it. You need something to hold the 8mm bar in it's horizontal position while the spool spins. I used two 8mm threaded bars as pillars with two "vertical_support.stl" on top of them, but you can use anything you want. The less the spool opposes force while it spins, the better is for the printer. An easy to move spool can make a difference on your printed parts Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-YkU3YFIYhw

description.text:
This is a model rocket that allows you to have the winglets pointed down if you put the vertical fin on one side of the fuselage, or pointed up if you glue it on the other.  
WIth 4 of these designs done, and at least one that has flown, I am thinking of offering these rockets as kits printed on my Solidoodle.  If interested, please contact me here.  
I am also planning on converting some hand drawn plans for a WWII canard fighter (it looks like 1/6th scale) to CAD so that I can print the entire model airplane (except for the wing and fuselage skins).  Anyone interested in that?  The plane is the Shinden and is available as a model kit everywhere, but not printed obviously and I have yet to see one this big.  
**Update: Seems my Solidoodle doesn't like my winglets and doesn't quite slice my nose cone with the cockpit bulge too well.  I may have to remove the winglets and split all the parts into separate STLs

comments.text: Nice!  Check out my design...similar in some ways.  Can you make this fly? I am sure you can...if I make this I will modify for c65 and post video...:)
comments.author: sparramore

comments.text: I did get a version to fly last year but I had to take the dihedral out of the wing tips.  I also added a second rudder and got rid of the canopy on the nosecone.  I flew it on C6-5s and C6-3s.  The coupler on the top of the main body should be removed and made thinner.  That's what I did (I just broke it off).  The coupler adds too much weight and the first flight was a little labored.  I highly recommend you treat the surfaces with XTC3D since the second version actually broke in half during ejection (I used a D12-3 at the time).  The XTC-3D will smooth the surfaces and also bind the layers in resin.  It will add weight, so I would actually widen the engine compartment enough to take a D class motor to accommodate the extra weight.  Oh and one more thing, drill 2 holes in the second body tube and thread the shock cord through them rather than glue a shock cord mount.  Far stronger and works perfectly.  Finally, make the parachute small, you really will do fine with a 12", and cut a spill hole in the parachute.  I actually used a streamer because it flew far and high and I was always worried about losing it.  I'll take a peek at your design(s) now and comment there.
comments.author: sparramore

comments.text: Being able to print a model Shinden would be amazing!  There's definitely interest!
comments.author: planes891

comments.text: In order to make this happen, I will look to print each bulkhead and rib as a separate item.  Builders will still have to figure out what electronics to build in and how to lay them out.  And of course, the fuselage has to be covered.....unless I attempt to make this thing as fuselage sections that you print and then superglue together.  I wish I was better with CAD, but even though I'm an engineer, I'm teaching myself in my spare time.  What I really want to do is build it in 1/12th scale, then 1/6th, then 1/3.  Of course, as an airplane homebuilder, 1/3 scale means I can sit in it, but at that that point I'd be CNC-ing the ribs and bulkheads out of sheet aluminum and cutting foam.

Something I made as a simple way of testing components and getting power to lashed together test circuits. My own model from scratch, but heavily influenced by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:168522 Uses 0.6mm patch wire and a cheap slide switch from ebay (http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/351353359962?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT)

Printed in PLA, 0.1mm layers at 50mm/s  
Can be a pig to wire if the holes close up - i heated some wire with a soldering iron and pushed it through to open the holes.   
Hopefully the photos show the wiring clear enough. Some needle nose pliers help a lot pulling the wires through and bending them.

I wanted a low-resistance filament holder for my Printrbot simple metal that could take a 2KG roll.  None of the holders I could find were large enough for this and many of them position the filament on the printer itself but I wanted it desk-standing to reduce vibration and not put additional load on the Z axis.  
This is easily printable and only requires 2x 608 bearings (per spool) to make.  In addition it is easy to change filament, simply lift out spool and drop in a new one.

This prints on a Printrbot Simple Metal however only just fits within the build area, I had to disable the skirt to be able to print this.  
Printed at 0.3mm layer height throughout, I use 18% infill normally.  The bar wants to be fairly strong as it can sag, particularity on narrower spools.  
Print one of the holder, and a bar and pair of spool ends for each spool you want to be able to swap in.  Press the bearings into the spool ends, pass the bar through the centre of the spool and then slide the spool ends over the bar so they fit into the ends of the spool.  
I've included STL files for eSun and colorFabb filaments as that's the only two makes I have, the scad file is included to allow modification for other makes.  
Once printed the spool should spin freely, in fact mine rolls and un-rolls as the print head moves across the print.

title: 3m organic vapor adapter for RodLaird's Rep2/2X Scrubber

description.text: This is an adapter for the common 3M organic vapor cartridge to be used with RodLaird's Rep2/2x scrubber parts. You need to print out Jake's Middle fitting piece, and then this adapter to fit your 3M cartridge into Jake's Middle fitting piece. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:245644) Then you attach the fan, and, RodLaird's scrubber coupler, finally RodLaird's exhaust piece. I still need to make some adapter feet, so this is a thing in pogress. Use this 3M organic vapor cartridge: http://www.amazon.com/3M-6001PB1-1-Organ-Vapor-2-Pack/dp/B001FNMW20/ref=sr_1_8?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1441482977&sr=1-8&keywords=3m+6001 I will be updating this as I progress. The first file has less stand off for the adapter. The 2nd file has an extra mm of stand off, to accommodate a gasket to improve the seal with the adapter.

comments.text: Have you had the chance to test your design? I had been working on using the same cartridge and Rod Laird's concept to build my own.  When I tested it, It didn't seem to have thru flow because wouldn't pull in solder smoke. I think the abrupt change from the small cartridge hole to the 60mm fan was causing a lot of turbulence.  My latest version has a large carbon water filter and fan.  I hope to put it online within the next two weeks.

remixed_from.title: Screwless Toolless E3D v6 Fan Duct

title: RoBo R1 e3d V6 fan duct

description.text:
This is a remix on Novice Expert's fan duct system to better fit the R1 printer. The front duct now has a cutout on the left side to allow it to fit properly on the x carriage without pushing against with the x end stop switch. The rear duct Has been slightly shortened so that it no longer comes into contract with the heater block. The tolerance with the fans as also been fixed. These will print ready to fit a 40mm fan straight off of the bed. These as well as a few other overall changes to the design.   
See instructions for printing details.   
Big thanks to MarquisJohnson (Novice Expert) for the original design which not only looks great, but allows these to have a near perfect fit onto the x carriage.

Ok you can print this in just about anything, although I would recommend you use something that is not ABS and can withstand higher temps. PET+ would be best, but if nothing else you can just use PLA Print with minimum supports. You only want supports that contact the glass. Supports for the bridges on the inside of the duct have been drawn into place. Just snap them off when the print is finished. Print on a 20% infill Most importantly if you have a RoBo printer, do yourself a favor and go check out Novice Expert on youtube https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCBGNc_mOP_amZNrNj6lAwHg

author: lfenske

description.text: Stop rubber foot for nordic walking.

Fan Duct for PrintRite DIY 3D Printer I have an updated version here: http://thingiverse.com/thing:1012778 The updated version has a larger tube from the fan mount to the corner. And now I also have a 3rd and much improved, completely redesigned version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1242620

Print it out on its side as oriented in the STL file, attach to the front surface of the extruder carriage with double-sided foam tape.
Remove the existing extruder fan and move it to the duct. Drill some holes for the fan screws and mount the fan to the duct with some sheet metal screws. Install a new 40mm fan on the Extruder. Run a new pair of wires to supply constant 12V power to the fan on the extruder. I'm pretty sure the Extruder fan should be running all the time to maintain the correct temperature gradient inside the nozzle, not varied as it is from the factory. I also used this 12V constant power to run a section of LED strip under the carriage. It gets dark under there..

title: Filament Spool Holder No Support Or Added Parts #FilamentChallenge

description.text: I designed this compact Spool Holder with two key points in mind. The first being that it can be printed with no support; this means that it can be easily be produced by many different printers (both basic and the more advanced). The second point I had in mind was that it needed to not require any additional parts other than 3D printable plastic. I thought this would be a key design feature as if it say needed a skateboard bearing to work then many people would either not be able to make that part meaning they can't print the holder or they would have to spend some money to buy one. So to solve this common problem I searched around on thingiverse and found a compact bearing that would spin freely; and I came across this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451 I modified this well designed bearing in their customizer so that it would fit in my spool holder. So using this design and some basic work on Google Sketchup I created the stand. After making some designs I came up with the idea to use the hexagonal cut hole in the bearing along with the two stand pieces to form the stand. This means that I can now make other attachments with that hexagonal cut that can say go on top of a printer. This is extremely useful as it saves me printing whole new bearings which saves time and plastic. My 3D modelling work is not the best as this is probably the 10th thing I have ever designed and printed and the first I have ever uploaded to thingiverse but I hope you enjoy it. Make sure to read the instructions carefully before printing!

To print this spool holder you will need to print two of the Side Stands and Bearings (one for each side of the spool), four of the Nuts and one Hex Beam. The print settings I used are 20% Infill, and 0.3 layer height. I used PLA plastic but I have not yet tried ABS. If my Bearing does not fit your spool go to the customizer at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451
I recommend using 0.4 tolerance. If you have any questions please leave them in the comments :)

author: boobear

description.text: I needed to put up those small, 12"x12" mirrors you can get at any home improvement store or Wal Mart.  The normal "stick-on" style way of doing it was not going to work on the surface I was using so I remixed the original mirror corners using Sketchup.

I printed with 100% infill and .3 layer thickness using ABS. For the 4-slot mirror holders I used supports and printed them flat. For the other sizes I used a raft and printed them on their sides. To create a design you must print multiple copies of the different designs depending on where they will be placed. For instance to create a simple 2x2 design you will need the following:
Qty 1 - x4
Qty 3 - x2
Qty 1 - x2 with open side
Qty 3 - corner
Qty 1 - Open side corner You have to leave one side open in order to slide in the mirror after you've mounted the clip. Note: The x3 mount is for a stepping pattern.

description.text:
UPDATE (20160222) V_2-9 is the new design which contains a glock-style trigger safety. These are printed separately since I was having issues with the safety becoming trapped and not working properly. Separately these work amazing. Hope you guys enjoy.
https://youtu.be/175FRcxrerg (20151004) V_1-5 (Non-safety) This design has a Salient Arms International style look. I haven't tried yet but anticipate shrinkage depending on the filament you use. I would suggest increase the print by 1% on each axis, but like I wrote below, it will work at regular size with some sanding. Thanks for looking! Make sure you utilize the support material for the openings. Without increasing print dimensions, you just have to hand sand the inside of the holes a little to get the two pins in, very minimal work. You can fit them exactly how you want the tension to be on them. Printed it out in 1.5 hours, sanded the pin holes for all of 3 minutes and put the gun back together in 2 minutes. Very easy. Hope you guys enjoy.

comments.text: I don't have a heated bed for my printer and the raft that it would produce still caused warping and other issues with the print (at least that version of the software did). I found that scaffolding was a simple fix to create more reliable & even prints, not perfect but definitely better. I would create a simple structure at bed level of the design (in this case the little cylinder) and moved the model I wanted to print a few millimeters up (1mm to 3mm) so that it would sit on scaffolding. There was no special reason to the height of the scaffolding I was just playing with it to test if it worked. 2mm above the print bed was sufficient enough I found since 1mm wasn't tall enough sometimes to create a solid enough base (modified raft). 3mm worked as well but was a waste of material in the end, not a lot but some people may care. I hope this explains well enough for you. In the end the cylinder serves no mechanical importance/role in the function of the part AFTER the print is finished.

remixed_from.title: String remote release for RICOH THETA

description.text:
Update 2016 May:
  • Ricoh Theta added a self timer making this device less necessary. Hold the WiFi button down when turning on the camera and there will be a 5 second delay before taking the picture to get the camera into position. Alternatively use the phone app set select other durations.
    • The Ricoh Theta camera captures of full spherical panoramic image with no blind spot. Unfortunately the button to trigger the camera is very close to the lens resulting in the hand and an extra large thumb taking up most of the nadir. Thanks to futaba's design of his String remote release got me thinking on how to make a smaller trigger. This is what I came up with. Using the Thumb to trigger.
    https://theta360.com/s/sQX4sZTsCDBLhKYJ6ZkDIKFLE Using string trigger https://theta360.com/s/ajQVjdKtVAy0RblQeTi92Lid6 Those dark blobs are chips on one of my lenses. New Theta S is preordered. The silver tape is used to help hide the camera more in the nadir. The camera actually captures itself. Instead of capturing the white of the camera, the silver tape reflects the colors of the environment. This thing was made with Tinkercad.
    Holder: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kvliKyvfCa9
    Arm: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cxyDTXoVpbP
The two pieces fit together and hinge to allow the arm to push against the button when the string is made into a loop and pulled down.

A life-sized robothead of the robot Chappie from the movie Chappie.
This is a big project and still in progress as im installing electronics too.
Please share a photo if you make one.
See more of my work at instagram : klitgaard71 update 30/11-15
Added photos of Arduino support for the eyes.

I started designing Chappies head with only a few photos before the movie was released.
I use the free 123D design for designing all parts.
It is not movie accurate, but im still satisfied with the overall look as it is now.
The antenna-ears, the monobrow and the chin protection can all move by hand.
All is printed in gray ABS 0,2mm layer and using Simplify3D and my Creatr dual from Leapfrog.
See more of my work at instagram : klitgaard71

comments.text: I started printing the pieces and I started with the Head_L_side_Big.stl. I am using a Cubex Duo with 3rd party bulk filament, so I am using KISSlicer to prepare the file and format it for the Cubex.  I have not had luck with the supports you can add there.  I tried adding supports with MeshMixer and then using KISSlicer to prepare the print job with supports already added. This worked out pretty well.  I tried flipping the object over which seemed structurally to print it better but will have a bit of a rough surface where the antenna will attach. I found dialing back the density on MeshMixer makes odd little branching tree-like supports that come off pretty cleanly.  I am printing the rest of the pieces over the next couple days I will post some pics when I have them done. As for attaching it to the InMoov robot body.  I am also going to print the neck and base of the skull pieces and then see what I have to modify to get them to attach.  If it works out I will share my files.

Forgotten King is great, but the KS delivered more cards than can fit the box. So I designed a tray that doesn't take up all the space in the box, looks elegant and is usable directly on the table.  
Three layers: bottom tray (large and small cards) - Wood Wisp, top layer (large cards) - Leaves and a lid to keep the cards in place during transportation - Princess coin.  
I use magnets to keep the trays together. 4 square 3 x 3 x 1 mm magnets and 12 round magnets with a diameter of 2,5 mm and a length of 3 mm. The holes are already in the model. You can buy these magnets from Hobby stores or through the internet.  
Stores all cards that came in the kickstarter but without sleeves (not enough height). Usable for cards up to 88mm x 63mm and 63mm x 42mm.

description.text: Stand for coasters from 3P3D.
New idea for K8400 bearing cap. Don't know yet if it works. The one I printed was too stiff. It was supposed to work as a spring giving constant tension on steel rods.
Print it flat. It has 0.1 mm clearance beetween botom surface and support.
I should have made the wall a bit thiner but only noticed after printing. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gBUcCi8OdCL
Walls are 3mm thick 2 to 3 shells with 10% infill should be enough.
for two 120x120mm Fans
The thingy got the holes to be wall mounted. Simple way to tidy up on your desk This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/11wDXI5d6QX
I just decided to try this!  As of today, 9/5/15, I have NOT tested it.  Please send pictures or comment if you make this!

A simple box mod bottom feeder ofr mechanic lovers.
It mount a 18650 battery and 6 ml classic round bottle.
Size are: 90x46x24. What do u need to assembly ?
  • all the printer parts;
  • for the push button:

    a M3 bolt long 15 <> 17 mm;
    a spring;
    a M3 nut;
    a round faston

  • 6 ml round bottle;
  • a drip cap (there 3 different hole body version)
  • 16 magnets 3x1 mm
    • In one shot u can see the push button mount sequence. A short video (IT):
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=edhSnSAVne0 Update 14/09/2015
    Added a body version with hole for fatdaddy drip cap.
